dt: {bc}to put into action or service {bc}avail oneself of {bc}{sx|employ||}
{bc}to expend or consume by putting to use

dt.t: the house could {wi}use{/wi} a coat of paint

dt: {bc}to consume or take (liquor, drugs, etc.) regularly
{bc}to carry out a purpose or action by means of {bc}{sx|utilize||}

dt.t: {it}used{/it} him selfishly
{it}used{/it} the prisoners cruelly

dt: used in the past with {it}to{/it} to indicate a former fact or state

dt.t: we {it}used{/it} to go more often
didn't {wi}use{/wi} to smoke

pt: {sc}use{/sc} {sc}employ{/sc} {sc}utilize{/sc} mean to put into service especially to attain an end. {sc}use{/sc} implies availing oneself of something as a means or instrument to an end.

pt.t: willing to {it}use{/it} any means to achieve her ends

pt: {sc}employ{/sc} suggests the use of a person or thing that is available but idle, inactive, or disengaged.

pt.t: looking for better ways to {it}employ{/it} their skills

pt: {sc}utilize{/sc} may suggest the discovery of a new, profitable, or practical use for something.

pt.t: an old wooden bucket {it}utilized{/it} as a planter

shortdef: to put into action or service : avail oneself of : employ
to expend or consume by putting to use —often used with up

dt: {bc}the act or practice of employing something {bc}{sx|employment||}, {sx|application||}

dt.t: he made good {wi}use{/wi} of his spare time

dt: {bc}the fact or state of being used

dt.t: a dish in daily {wi}use{/wi}

dt: {bc}a method or manner of employing or applying something

dt.t: gained practice in the {wi}use{/wi} of the camera

dt: {bc}the privilege or benefit of using something

dt.t: gave him the {wi}use{/wi} of her car

dt: {bc}the ability or power to use something (such as a limb or faculty)
{bc}the legal enjoyment of property that consists in its employment, occupation, exercise, or practice

dt.t: put learning to practical {wi}use{/wi}

dt: {bc}the quality of being suitable for employment

dt.t: saving things that might be of {wi}use{/wi}
it's no {wi}use{/wi} arguing
took only what they had {wi}use{/wi} for
had no {wi}use{/wi} for modern art

dt: {bc}the benefit in law of one or more persons
{bc}the benefit or profit of property established in one other than the legal possessor
{bc}a legal arrangement by which such benefits and profits are so established
{bc}a liturgy having modifications peculiar to a local church or religious order

et: Middle English {it}us{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}usus{/it}, from {it}uti{/it} to use
shortdef: the act or practice of employing something : employment, application
the fact or state of being used
a method or manner of employing or applying something

dt: {bc}to exhaust of strength or useful properties

dt.t: land that has been {it}used up{/it}

shortdef: to exhaust of strength or useful properties

dt.t: Maybe if we {it}use our heads{/it}, we can figure this out.
I'm sure we can solve this problem if we just {it}use our heads{/it}.
"I don't understand the math homework." "{it}Use your noggin{/it} and apply the rules you've learned."

dt: used to say that something existed or repeatedly happened in the past but does not exist or happen now

dt.t: {it}Did{/it} you {it}use to{/it} work there?
It {it}didn't use to{/it} be like that.
He {it}didn't use to{/it} smoke.

shortdef: —used to say that something existed or repeatedly happened in the past but does not exist or happen now—used with did

dt: {bc}a medical condition characterized by a pattern of frequent and usually excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages, by strong cravings for alcohol often accompanied by episodes of depression, anxiety, or distress, by symptoms (such as restlessness or sweating) of alcohol withdrawal, and by the impaired ability to stop or control the intake of alcohol despite adverse effects on one's work, school, or family obligations

Alcohol use disorder ranges from mild to severe and is typically considered to encompass conditions also referred to as {it}alcohol dependence{/it}, {it}alcohol abuse{/it}, {it}alcohol addiction{/it}, and {it}alcoholism{/it}.

dt.t: Over the long term, teen alcohol use can interfere with normal brain development and can increase the chance that the teens will develop an {wi}alcohol use disorder{/wi} later in life.
About 40 to 50 soldiers assigned to Fort Meade are now undergoing treatment for {wi}alcohol use disorders{/wi}.

An estimated 18 million Americans suffer from {wi}alcohol-use disorder{/wi}, as the DSM-5, the latest edition of the American Psychiatric Association's diagnostic manual, calls it. … Only about 15 percent of those with {wi}alcohol-use disorder{/wi} are at the severe end of the spectrum. The rest fall somewhere in the mild-to-moderate range …

shortdef: a medical condition characterized by a pattern of frequent and usually excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages, by strong cravings for alcohol often accompanied by episodes of depression, anxiety, or distress, by symptoms (such as restlessness or sweating) of alcohol withdrawal, and by the impaired ability to stop or control the intake of alcohol despite adverse effects on one's work, school, or family obligations —abbreviation AUD

dt: {bc}a legal doctrine that portions of copyrighted materials may be used without permission of the copyright owner provided the use is fair and reasonable, does not substantially impair the value of the materials, and does not curtail the profits reasonably expected by the owner

shortdef: a legal doctrine that portions of copyrighted materials may be used without permission of the copyright owner provided the use is fair and reasonable, does not substantially impair the value of the materials, and does not curtail the profits reasonably expected by the owner
